content.html: I believe @microdotblog is the closest I've seen to "a tool that helps bring the entire system together in one place."
content.text: I believe @microdotblog is the closest I've seen to "a tool that helps bring the entire system together in one place."
Can‚Äôt smash the Like button hard enough for what Miriam Suzanne has to say on the challenging technical hurdles of implementing Webmentions‚Ä¶

Ok, here it is. A slow reply to @chriscoyier's RSS post, and a test of my new webmentions setup. 

Am I on the IndieWeb Yet?

(Even if mentions work, they won't display yet. I wasn't happy doing a theoretical layout of content I don't yet grok.)

miriamsuzanne.com/2022/06/04/ind‚Ä¶

content.html: Maybe. I was imagining more like browser devtool/plugins to visualize & inspect the 'result' of the code. With RSS, I'd want a built-in reader to view a rendered feed (rather than plain xml) when I navigate to the url. Mentions are a bit more complicated tho. Not sure.

content.html: This sounds interesting. Just making sure I understand, would this be like a lint tool of sorts that you'd run locally and point at URLs? (jacky.wtf/2022/6/JsFH)
content.text: This sounds interesting. Just making sure I understand, would this be like a lint tool of sorts that you'd run locally and point at URLs? (jacky.wtf/2022/6/JsFH)

content.html: Ahh, that would be _super_ handy (and is probably simpler to implement). I asked because I had an idea that I've been pecking at for a ‚ÄúIndieWeb linting‚Äù tool, but a browser extension feels like the more natural place for something like this. (jacky.wtf/2022/6/FYYI)

children.name: Am I on the IndieWeb Yet? - Miriam Eric Suzanne

content.text: I enjoyed this read. It's always worth coming back to the difficulties in the social IndieWeb features, and how tricky they are to implement. I've invested substantial effort in webmentions in particular, and that means there's a barrier to entry.

content.html: Right now I think if I had a full day-or-two to dedicate to it I‚Äôm not sure I could pull it off. Particularly the ‚Äúif someone tweets a comment, pull it into my own DB and display it automatically‚Äù. Too hard.
content.text: Right now I think if I had a full day-or-two to dedicate to it I‚Äôm not sure I could pull it off. Particularly the ‚Äúif someone tweets a comment, pull it into my own DB and display it automatically‚Äù. Too hard.

author.name: Tab is short for Tab Atkins-Bittner

content.html:
Like Am I on the IndieWeb Yet? | Miriam Eric Suzanne...

_I‚Äôm an experienced web developer, and I can figure it out. But the steps aren‚Äôt simple, and most of my friends are not web developers. So, to me, this all feels like the prototype of an idea ‚Äì a proof of concept. ... What I would like to see is a tool that helps bring the entire system together in one place.

It's a shame that we're still talking about this in these terms. Yes, there are more implementations out there and libraries you can use in your own code but it's still too hard for most people.

But it's not just a code & complexity issue. For the IndieWeb to grow people need to be convinced of the benefits of running their own site and owning their own data ‚Äî an almost herculean task when faced with the size, simplicity and convenience of the centralised social platforms.

The world and web have moved on.
content.text:
Like Am I on the IndieWeb Yet? | Miriam Eric Suzanne...

_I‚Äôm an experienced web developer, and I can figure it out. But the steps aren‚Äôt simple, and most of my friends are not web developers. So, to me, this all feels like the prototype of an idea ‚Äì a proof of concept.
...
What I would like to see is a tool that helps bring the entire system together in one place.

It's a shame that we're still talking about this in these terms. Yes, there are more implementations out there and libraries you can use in your own code but it's still too hard for most people.
But it's not just a code & complexity issue. For the IndieWeb to grow people need to be convinced of the benefits of running their own site and owning their own data ‚Äî an almost herculean task when faced with the size, simplicity and convenience of the centralised social platforms.
The world and web have moved on.
I haven‚Äôt signed to any major web labels.

children.name: Am I already on IndieWeb? | CSS tips

content.html:
I can‚Äôt mash the like button hard enough for what Miriam Suzanne has to say on the difficult technical hurdles of implementing Webmentions:

The first round required several online services as well as HTML and JS changes to my static site, just to verify my indieweb identity. Next, more changes to the site and more online services to help recover all mentions (so far, nothing to see, but it‚Äôs probably planned). It seems the only way to test the setup is to release all these changes publicly and then ask other developers to send you endorsements.

[‚Ä¶]

I‚Äôm an experienced web developer and I can figure it out. But the steps are not simple, and most of my friends are not web developers. So, to me, this all sounds like the prototype of an idea ‚Äì a proof of concept.

A proof of concept for sure. And one that has been around for a while. The IndeWeb The idea of ‚Äã‚Äãowning your own data and using your website as a social hub is well within my reach ‚Äì and probably yours too, as someone working on the front end.

Still, I tinkered with it from time to time ‚Äì especially Website Citations ‚Äì over the past three years with little to show for it. The problem is not so much the startup documentation because Everything is here. It‚Äôs more of a combination of things‚Ä¶

  • The wiki is confusing. Wikis are super cool in general, but their non-linear nature makes it hard to know where to start and where to end.
  • The plugin ecosystem is complex. My personal site is on WordPress and there is a plugin designed to help integrate IndieWeb functionality. Except it‚Äôs really a plugin that tricks you into installing several more, each introducing technology that I honestly have a hard time understanding.
  • There are a lot of terms to learn. I mean, ‚ÄúIndieWeb‚Äù and ‚ÄúWebmention‚Äù are hard enough to understand. Add things like ‚ÄúMicropub‚Äù, ‚ÄúMicroformats‚Äù, ‚ÄúIndieAuth‚Äù, and ‚ÄúSemantic Linkbacks‚Äù, and suddenly it looks like a bunch of jigsaw pieces from different puzzles trying to fit together.
  • Do you think middleware is necessary? For example, I had to give a service called Brigitte access to my Twitter to start this activity. This Apparently has something to do with the Twitter shortcut t.co URLs and make them play well with microformats.

But, like Miriam, I struggled to get by and finally got something to work. This is the kind of visual I wish I had when I started, and maybe it will help you too.

That‚Äôs a lot to kick off Webmentions, but maybe that‚Äôs only because I have such a light understanding of the technology and how it all fits together. All the pieces are there, though, and even with the initial struggle, I love the IndieWeb concept, uh the prototype.

Direct link ‚Üí

Share this:
content.text:
I can‚Äôt mash the like button hard enough for what Miriam Suzanne has to say on the difficult technical hurdles of implementing Webmentions:

The first round required several online services as well as HTML and JS changes to my static site, just to verify my indieweb identity.  Next, more changes to the site and more online services to help recover all mentions (so far, nothing to see, but it‚Äôs probably planned).  It seems the only way to test the setup is to release all these changes publicly and then ask other developers to send you endorsements.
[‚Ä¶]
I‚Äôm an experienced web developer and I can figure it out.  But the steps are not simple, and most of my friends are not web developers.  So, to me, this all sounds like the prototype of an idea ‚Äì a proof of concept.

A proof of concept for sure.  And one that has been around for a while.  The IndeWeb The idea of ‚Äã‚Äãowning your own data and using your website as a social hub is well within my reach ‚Äì and probably yours too, as someone working on the front end.

Still, I tinkered with it from time to time ‚Äì especially Website Citations ‚Äì over the past three years with little to show for it.  The problem is not so much the startup documentation because Everything is here.  It‚Äôs more of a combination of things‚Ä¶

The wiki is confusing. Wikis are super cool in general, but their non-linear nature makes it hard to know where to start and where to end.

The plugin ecosystem is complex. My personal site is on WordPress and there is a plugin designed to help integrate IndieWeb functionality.  Except it‚Äôs really a plugin that tricks you into installing several more, each introducing technology that I honestly have a hard time understanding.

There are a lot of terms to learn. I mean, ‚ÄúIndieWeb‚Äù and ‚ÄúWebmention‚Äù are hard enough to understand.  Add things like ‚ÄúMicropub‚Äù, ‚ÄúMicroformats‚Äù, ‚ÄúIndieAuth‚Äù, and ‚ÄúSemantic Linkbacks‚Äù, and suddenly it looks like a bunch of jigsaw pieces from different puzzles trying to fit together.

Do you think middleware is necessary? For example, I had to give a service called Brigitte access to my Twitter to start this activity.  This Apparently has something to do with the Twitter shortcut t.co URLs and make them play well with microformats.
But, like Miriam, I struggled to get by and finally got something to work.  This is the kind of visual I wish I had when I started, and maybe it will help you too.
That‚Äôs a lot to kick off Webmentions, but maybe that‚Äôs only because I have such a light understanding of the technology and how it all fits together.  All the pieces are there, though, and even with the initial struggle, I love the IndieWeb concept, uh the prototype.
